repnme.cdata!:
Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia -
            First, Second, and Third Programmatic Development Policy
            Loans Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Programmatic Development Policy Loans (PDPL) Project for
            Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was modest, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the experience of parts of the human
            resources sub-component of the PDPL confirms the importance
            of 'ownership' and 'criticality' as good
            practice principles for development policy loan operations.
            The lack of clear ownership by the authorities and the
            assessment that the prior action is not critical to
            achieving results might have contributed to the partial
            achievement of some of the program objectives and could be
            interpreted as suggesting that a more narrow focus will have
            been more appropriate. At the same time, the experience of
            the decentralization sub-component of the program suggests
            that a broader focus could be supported provided the good
            practice principles are met. This subcomponent was not
            necessarily central to either pillar one or two, but its
            inclusion in the PDPL helped avert a potential derailing of
            this area of reform. The PDPL team tried to secure a buy-in
            for the supported reforms from as many groups, particularly
            the opposition, as possible. This approach paid off as the
            change in government between PDPL two and three did not
            result in backtracking on the reform program. Also, the new
            law on labor balanced the interests of the parties through
            stakeholder involvement, which made its passage faster. The
            participatory process by which the law was prepared also
            improved negotiating sills of relevant stakeholders, which
            will be useful for negotiations in the future.

6501936.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Rule of law,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            First Programatic Development Policy Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Programmatic Development
            Policy Loan for Macedonia will promote economic growth and
            job creation in FYR Macedonia through improving: (i) the
            investment climate; and (ii) governance and efficiency of
            the public sector. The proposed programmatic development
            policy loans (PDPLs) will be designed to ensure consistency
            with the Government's aspiration of eventual European
            Union (EU) accession.  The proposed PDPLs will follow up on
            the reforms initiated under the recent Public Sector
            Management Adjustment Loan (PSMAL) and the Second Financial
            and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Loan (FESAL 2) as well as
            the reforms identified in the recent Financial Sector
            Assessment Program (FSAP).
